articles.title: NOVEMBER 1987
articles.summary: This document outlines a series of events for November and early December 1987. It details general meetings, including one focused on 'BUILDING THE SPACE STATION' with Leslie Wickman from Lockheed and another featuring NASA films. Also listed are board meetings, field expeditions for astronomical observation at Fremont Peak State Park, and an indoor star party, primarily held at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: The article from SJAA announces renewal information for Astromedia publications like Astronomy and Telescope Making magazines, detailing club rates, independent conversion options, and the November 7th deadline. It also promotes the upcoming General Meeting on November 7th, featuring Leslie Wickman from Lockheed, who will discuss the construction and maintenance of space structures, including the Space Station and Space Telescope, using an underwater simulator.

articles.title: DON MACHHOLZ RECEIVES GREGORY AWARD
articles.summary: Don Machholz was honored with the Dr. A.B. Gregory award at the SJAA General Meeting for his significant contributions to amateur astronomy. He is recognized for sharing his enthusiasm for comets and observing with the SJAA, school groups, scout troops, and the media, and for discovering three comets. Machholz also played a key role in public outreach during the 1985-86 appearance of Halley's Comet.

articles.title: ART OF THE COSMOS EXHIBIT AT LHS
articles.summary: The 'ART OF THE COSMOS' exhibit will showcase over sixty artistic depictions of the Universe, featuring works by renowned artists such as Andrew Chaikin and Ralph McQuarrie. Running from November 21, 1987, to February 14, 1988, at Lick High School Science in the San Francisco Bay Area, the collection includes both scientifically accurate and abstract pieces, each with explanatory captions. Admission details and operating hours are provided for this unique blend of art and astronomy.

articles.title: A PROGRAM ABOUT EINSTEIN AND HIS WORK
articles.summary: A two-day non-technical program titled "Einstein: The Man and His Legacy" will be presented by astronomer Andrew Fraknoi and physicist Sidney Drell on November 7 and 8 at U.C. Berkeley. The program, open to the public for $75, will cover Einstein's life, theories of relativity, influence on science and culture, black holes, and new ideas of gravity. No prior science background is assumed, and the event aims to make complex topics accessible.

articles.title: SHERWOOD HARRINGTON WINS AAMC AWARD OF MERIT
articles.summary: Sherwood Harrington, Education Coordinator of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific, received the 1987 Award of Merit from the Astronomical Association of Northern California for his outstanding contributions to fostering amateur astronomy. He is recognized for developing educational materials, co-authoring publications like Mercury and The Universe in the Classroom, and creating the popular A.S.P. Hotline. Harrington also serves as an astronomy instructor at City College of San Francisco and designed its observatory and curricula.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document features a classifieds section for astronomical equipment, offering a variety of used telescopes including Cassegrains, reflectors, refractors, and Schmidt-Cassegrains from brands like Tinsley, Coulter, Meade, and Celestron. It also lists various accessories such as focusers, eyepieces, mounts, tripods, and specialized optical windows. Additionally, there is a reward offered for information leading to the recovery of a stolen telescope mirror.

articles.title: BY: BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: This article provides updates on several space programs: the successful testing of a redesigned space shuttle solid booster, ongoing political and international disagreements surrounding the Space Station program's funding and structure, the resumption of European Ariane launches after a redesign, and the launch of a Soviet biological spacecraft with international participation. Key issues include congressional funding battles for the Space Station, the U.S. Defense Secretary's stance on military use of the station, and disagreements over international management.

articles.title: SOVIETS TESTING JET-POWERED SPACE SHUTTLE
articles.summary: The Soviets are reportedly conducting runway takeoff and landing tests with a jet-powered version of their space shuttle orbiter. This orbiter, fitted with four 20,000 lb. Lyulka engines, is simulating approach and landing profiles for re-entry. Although the first flight is planned to be unmanned, the Soviet cosmonaut corps has not received this well.

articles.title: NEW MODULE TO BE ADDED TO THE MIR SPACE STATION
articles.summary: A new extravehicular activity (EVA) airlock module is scheduled to be added to the Mir space station. This new module will be comparable in size to the Kvant astrophysics module previously added, weighing 24,250 lbs.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article, 'Comet Comments' by Don Machholz, provides an update on recent comet activity, noting a record-breaking 24 comets discovered or recovered this year. While bright Comet Bradfield, along with Borrelly, Rudenko, and Wilson, are currently visible, newly discovered Comet Helin and recovered Periodic Comets Gehrels 1 and West-Kohoutek-Ikemura remain faint, with details on their discovery, orbital periods, and expected brightness.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This article provides ephemerides and observational notes for two comets, Bradfield (1987s) and Rudenko (1987u), covering late October through early December. Comet Bradfield (1987s) is performing better than expected, is easily visible with binoculars, and is the brightest comet for Northern Hemisphere observers through March. Conversely, Comet Rudenko (1987u) is rapidly moving south, will become unobservable for Northern Hemisphere viewers by Thanksgiving, and is predicted to be much fainter upon its return in January.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p)
articles.summary: This document provides an observing guide for Periodic Comet Borrelly (1987p) from October to early December, noting its fainter-than-expected magnitude. It highlights the comet's closest approach to Earth on December 8th (0.48 AU), predicting it will appear large and diffuse, and details its northward movement across the sky, becoming visible nearly all night.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT BY JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: This article discusses Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS), tracing its historical observations from Cassini in 1665 to its renewed attention in the late 19th century, noting its erratic motion makes precise long-term predictions difficult. The author details his method for tracking the GRS and providing corrected predictions for optimal viewing times. Practical advice for observing the GRS is provided, including recommended equipment, magnification, filters, and techniques to discern the feature.

articles.title: Great Red Spot Observations - July-December 1981
articles.summary: This article details observations of Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) between July and December 1981 from Maricotta, Michigan. The GRS was recovered on July 25th, appearing yellowish with a white southern edge, similar to the previous year's visibility. Later observations suggested the GRS was larger than usual, taking 40 minutes to cross Jupiter's central meridian, and observers are encouraged to experiment with different magnifications and filters, reporting their findings.

articles.title: Great Red Spot on Meridian PST
articles.summary: This document provides a schedule of dates and times when Jupiter's Great Red Spot will transit the meridian, as observed in Pacific Standard Time (PST). It covers events from late October through early December, offering a guide for observers interested in viewing this prominent feature.

articles.title: A PRODUCT EVALUATION BY JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: John Gleason provides a product evaluation of the Celestron Compustar, a computer-controlled telescope accessory designed to automate object finding. While praising its ease of use for locating deep-sky objects and significant improvements over a prototype, he highlights critical flaws like a pulsatile RA drive motor that severely impacts astrophotography and high-magnification observing. The article also compares the Compustar to the similar C.A.T. system, discussing the viability and philosophical implications of such technology for amateur astronomers.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA hosts monthly General Meetings at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, offering talks from speakers on diverse astronomical topics and featuring "Indoor Star Parties" for members to share astrophotography. These gatherings provide a friendly atmosphere for all astronomy enthusiasts, with specific directions and start times also detailed.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) hosts monthly 'Indoor Star Parties' on Saturday evenings, providing informal gatherings for amateur astronomers to connect and share their passion. Attendees can bring telescopes, view astrophotography, participate in an Introductory Astronomy workshop, or attend SJAA Board Meetings. These events foster community and shared learning among astronomy enthusiasts.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays closest to the New Moon. These field expeditions are held at various locations, ranging from close to San Jose to as far as Yosemite National Park, with directions found in the EPHEMERIS.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a highly popular observing site for Bay Area amateur astronomers, located 70 miles south of San Jose. Known for serious deep sky observing and astrophotography during New Moon weekends, it also houses the Fremont Peak Observatory Association's 30-inch telescope, open to the public. The article provides detailed directions and notes that the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) often gathers there, with dozens of telescopes present during summer months.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing various membership options and their costs, including a "Membership Only" option, a "Membership/S&T" option, and a "Junior (Under 18)" membership. The form requests applicant contact information and specifies submission instructions, allowing for both in-person submission at meetings or mailing to the SJAA Treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document is an optional questionnaire from the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) designed to gather information on individuals' astronomical interests (e.g., astrophotography, deep-sky observation, telescope making), telescope ownership, and areas of expertise they might be willing to share. It serves as a tool for member engagement and is marked as time-sensitive news material.
